awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Transforming Additive Nanomanufacturing with Machine Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Optoelectronic substrates form a critical component in a variety of functional devices where the substrate functions to allow light to pass through and, at the same time, protect the device from the ambient environment. Applications include displays, solar cells, smart phones, tablets, light emitting diodes (LEDs), as well as emerging flexible versions of these optoelectronic devices such as radio frequency identification (RFID) tags, artificial skin, and e-paper. The availability of high performance, optoelectronic devices greatly impacts technologies such as wearables, the Internet of Things, and more, thus contributing to the nation's economy and security. Currently, rigid glass substrates are typically used with an antireflection layer. However, these coatings do not provide for antireflection across a wide range of wavelengths or angles and lack other desired multi-functionality. This EArly-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) program award supports research to create a framework for applying machine learning methods to nanomanufacturing processes. A specific goal is to utilize the machine learning and optimization approach to design and construct nanophotonic structures on surfaces to achieve different optical properties such as anti-fogging and anti-bacterial. Additive nanomanufacturing is a versatile method to create complex 3D structures with nano-scale features. Since many surface engineering designs and functions are possible, a machine learning approach is needed. The project studies nanomanufacturing approaches involving maskless and scalable etching and deposition processes that are commonly used in the semiconductor device fabrication industry. This research activity is highly multidisciplinary and exemplifies the unique role that industrial engineering and materials engineering play in the future of nanomanufacturing research and in training the future workforce.

The project creates a framework that integrates nanomanufacturing methods, such as reactive ion etching, with machine learning and optimization tools, physical simulations, and multi-functional characterizations to demonstrate durable and flexible nanostructured optoelectronic substrates with high performance photon management properties, such as antireflection and haze management. Most of the recent work in surface engineering of multi-functional nanostructure coatings for a wide variety of rigid and emerging flexible optoelectronic devices has involved traditional trial-and-error approaches that offer, at best, fragmented and limited systematic studies of small regions of the parameter space absent any embedded historical knowledge. Major challenges exist in demonstrating the scalability of manufacturing processes. This research seeks to test the hypothesis that a machine learning and optimization framework can be utilized to more rapidly design and engineer optoelectronic substrates compared to current incremental approaches. Machine learning methods are integrated to fit experimental data, predict the performance of new structures, and provide heuristics for additional experiments. Current limitations are overcome through the creation of new machine learning methods that succinctly learn nanostructure-additive NanoManufacturing-property relationships with the ability to generalize across domains. Machine learning models are developed to determine how to manufacture 3D nanostructured surfaces on glass and plastics using additive nanomanufacturing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded EAGER project demonstrates new optoelectronic surfaces critical for devices like solar cells, smartphones, and LEDs. By integrating machine learning with nanomanufacturing techniques, we develop flexible, high-performance surfaces with enhanced optical properties such as anti-fogging and anti-bacterial functions. This multidisciplinary effort overcomes limitations of traditional rigid glass substrates and paves the way for next-generation technologies in areas like wearable tech and the Internet of Things.

 

Advancements from this project include:

  1. Innovative 3D Printed Structures: We have developed 3D printed re-entrant micropillars and microcell/nanoparticle structures, achieving high static contact angles with various liquids, indicative of superior water-repellency. These structures maintain super-repellency even after significant mechanical abrasion, marking a significant improvement in durability and functionality.
  2. Bio-Inspired Multi-Functional Substrates: The project has summarized extensive research in bio-inspired multifunctional transparent substrates used in various optoelectronic devices. These substrates offer improved photon management properties, durability, and can be utilized in both traditional and flexible device formats.
  3. Convexification of Optimization Problems: The team has made strides in the convexification of quadratic optimization problems with indicator variables and combinatorial constraints, crucial for enhancing machine learning algorithms' efficiency and accuracy.
  4. Robust Classification Trees: To address noisy data issues, we have developed a mixed-integer optimization formulation for learning optimal classification trees that are robust to adversarial perturbations. This method has shown significant improvements in worst-case and average-case accuracy across various datasets.
  5. Optimal Binary Classification Trees: We have proposed a novel mixed-integer optimization formulation for learning optimal binary classification trees, resulting in faster computation times and improved out-of-sample performance.
  6. Electrodynamic Simulation Datasets and Benchmarks: The project introduced frameworks to evaluate nanophotonic structures, crucial for designing devices like solar cells and LEDs. These evaluations assist in identifying optimal structures based on desired optical properties.
  7. Multi-fidelity Multi-objective Optimization: A novel Multi-BOWS framework has been introduced to design optical devices, balancing multiple objectives and using multi-fidelity evaluations. This method has shown significant improvements in designing nanophotonic structures for applications like transparent electromagnetic shielding.

The results from this project integrate nanomanufacturing and machine learning with promising implications for a range of optoelectronic applications.

 


Last Modified: 01/05/2024
Modified by: Paul W Leu

This multidisciplinary effort overcomes limitations of traditional rigid glass substrates and paves the way for next-generation technologies in areas like wearable tech and the Internet of Things.





Advancements from this project include:

Innovative 3D Printed Structures: We have developed 3D printed re-entrant micropillars and microcell/nanoparticle structures, achieving high static contact angles with various liquids, indicative of superior water-repellency. These structures maintain super-repellency even after significant mechanical abrasion, marking a significant improvement in durability and functionality.
Bio-Inspired Multi-Functional Substrates: The project has summarized extensive research in bio-inspired multifunctional transparent substrates used in various optoelectronic devices. Electrodynamic Simulation Datasets and Benchmarks: The project introduced frameworks to evaluate nanophotonic structures, crucial for designing devices like solar cells and LEDs. These evaluations assist in identifying optimal structures based on desired optical properties.
Multi-fidelity Multi-objective Optimization: A novel Multi-BOWS framework has been introduced to design optical devices, balancing multiple objectives and using multi-fidelity evaluations. This method has shown significant improvements in designing nanophotonic structures for applications like transparent electromagnetic shielding.



The results from this project integrate nanomanufacturing and machine learning with promising implications for a range of optoelectronic applications.
